02487 /**
02488  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_int_ena_w1c
02489  */
02490 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_int_ena_w1c {
02491     uint64_t u64;
02492     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_int_ena_w1c_s {
02493 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
02494     uint64_t reserved_11_63               : 53;
02495     uint64_t sli_err                      : 1;  /**< A DPI DMA or CPU read to the NQM (i.e. PEM0 PF2) function returned with
02496                                                          an error. This could be because of a bad pointer, FLR, or other reasons
02497                                                          related to the function. An FLR when there are inflight reads to the remote host
02498                                                          function can cause [SLI_ERR] to assert when the reads would normally
02499                                                          complete successfully. During an FLR, it is possible for [SLI_ERR] to
02500                                                          continually be set while DPI drains DMA instructions reading the
02501                                                          function that were queued before the FLR.
02502                                                          In the DPI DMA case where the instruction that caused [SLI_ERR] to
02503                                                          be set generates a completion status, DPI_CS_E::ERRRSP is the completion
02504                                                          status for the DPI DMA instruction.
02505                                                          When an FLR was not the [SLI_ERR] assertion cause, [SLI_ERR] assertion
02506                                                          should typically coincide with one or more completions with a data transfer
02507                                                          error (value 4) status code. When an FLR was the cause, NQM hardware
02508                                                          will have recently sent [FLR]. */
02509     uint64_t sq_fe                        : 1;  /**< Submission queue fatal error. NQM asserts [SQ_FE] when a PRP list entry
02510                                                          read from a SQ in the function completes with an error status.
02511                                                          This could be because of a bad PRP list pointer, FLR, or other reasons
02512                                                          related to the function. An FLR can cause [SQ_FE] to assert for a
02513                                                          normally-operating SQ that is not idle when the FLR is initiated.
02514                                                          The SQ(s) causing [SQ_FE] to assert must have NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0,
02515                                                          and NQM clears their NQM_VF()_SQ()_BASE[PRIP,BV]=0,0, and
02516                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE]=0 when the error occurs.
02517                                                          When an FLR was not the [SQ_FE] assertion cause, [SQ_FE] assertion
02518                                                          should result in a controller fatal error reported back to the host
02519                                                          via NQM_VF()_CSTS[CFS]. When an FLR was the cause, NQM will have
02520                                                          set [FLR]. */
02521     uint64_t cq_fe                        : 1;  /**< Completion queue fatal error. NQM asserts [CQ_FE] when a PRP list entry
02522                                                          read from a CQ in the function completes with an error status.
02523                                                          This could be because of a bad PRP list pointer, FLR, or other reasons
02524                                                          related to the function. An FLR can cause [CQ_FE] to assert for a
02525                                                          normally-operating CQ that is not idle when the FLR is initiated.
02526                                                          The CQ(s) causing [CQ_FE] to assert must have NQM_VF()_CQ()_CC[PC]=0,
02527                                                          and NQM clears their NQM_VF()_CQ()_BASE[PRIP,BV]=0,0, and
02528                                                          NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE]=0 when the error occurs.
02529                                                          When an FLR was not the [CQ_FE] assertion cause, [CQ_FE] assertion
02530                                                          should result in a controller fatal error reported back to the host
02531                                                          via NQM_VF()_CSTS[CFS]. When an FLR was the cause, NQM will have
02532                                                          set [FLR]. */
02533     uint64_t asq_cfg                      : 1;  /**< Administration submission queue configuration. Asserted when the host
02534                                                          changes the configuration of the admin SQ while it is enabled.
02535                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes admin SQ enable conditions.
02536                                                          This error should typically result in a controller fatal error
02537                                                          reported back to the host via NQM_VF()_CSTS[CFS]. */
02538     uint64_t acq_cfg                      : 1;  /**< Administration completion queue configuration. Asserted when the host
02539                                                          changes the configuration of the admin CQ while it is enabled.
02540                                                          NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes admin CPL/CQ enable conditions.
02541                                                          This error should typically result in a controller fatal error
02542                                                          reported back to the host via NQM_VF()_CSTS[CFS]. */
02543     uint64_t cq_db_val                    : 1;  /**< Completion queue doorbell value: Asserted when host software writes a
02544                                                          doorbell value via PCIe that exceeds the size of the CQ, or is the
02545                                                          same as the previous written value or attempts to remove from an
02546                                                          empty CQ (underflow) while enabled. NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE]
02547                                                          describes CPL/CQ enable conditions.
02548                                                          This error should typically result in software posting an invalid
02549                                                          doorbell write value (value 1) error status asynchronous event to the
02550                                                          host. */
02551     uint64_t cq_db                        : 1;  /**< Completion queue doorbell. Asserted when host software writes the
02552                                                          doorbell of a CQ that is disabled. NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE]
02553                                                          describes CPL/CQ enable conditions.
02554                                                          This error should typically result in software posting an invalid
02555                                                          doorbell register (value 0) error status asynchronous event to the host. */
02556     uint64_t sq_db_val                    : 1;  /**< Submission queue doorbell value: Asserted when host software writes a
02557                                                          doorbell value via PCIe that exceeds the size of the SQ, or is the
02558                                                          same as the previous written value or attempts to add to a full SQ
02559                                                          (overflow) while enabled. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes
02560                                                          SQ enable conditions.
02561                                                          This error should typically result in software posting an invalid
02562                                                          doorbell write value (value 1) error status asynchronous event to the
02563                                                          host. */
02564     uint64_t sq_db                        : 1;  /**< Submission queue doorbell. Asserted when host software writes the
02565                                                          doorbell of a SQ that is disabled. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes
02566                                                          SQ enable conditions.
02567                                                          This error should typically result in software posting an invalid
02568                                                          doorbell register (value 0) error status asynchronous event to the host. */
02569     uint64_t flr                          : 1;  /**< Function-level reset interrupt.  This bit is asserted when a PCIe
02570                                                          function-level reset to the function has been initiated. */
02571     uint64_t ccw                          : 1;  /**< Controller configuration write interrupt.  This bit is asserted anytime
02572                                                          the NQM_VF()_CC register is written via PCIe.  This can be used to
02573                                                          notify OCTEON software that the shutdown notification (SHN) and/or
02574                                                          the enable (EN) fields have changed. */
02575 #else
02576     uint64_t ccw                          : 1;
02577     uint64_t flr                          : 1;
02578     uint64_t sq_db                        : 1;
02579     uint64_t sq_db_val                    : 1;
02580     uint64_t cq_db                        : 1;
02581     uint64_t cq_db_val                    : 1;
02582     uint64_t acq_cfg                      : 1;
02583     uint64_t asq_cfg                      : 1;
02584     uint64_t cq_fe                        : 1;
02585     uint64_t sq_fe                        : 1;
02586     uint64_t sli_err                      : 1;
02587     uint64_t reserved_11_63               : 53;
02588 #endif
02589     } s;
02590     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_int_ena_w1c_s     cn73xx;

02771                                                          doorbell value via PCIe that exceeds the size of the SQ, or is the
02772                                                          same as the previous written value or attempts to add to a full SQ
02773                                                          (overflow) while enabled. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes
02774                                                          SQ enable conditions.
02775                                                          This error should typically result in software posting an invalid
02776                                                          doorbell write value (value 1) error status asynchronous event to the
02777                                                          host. */
02778     uint64_t sq_db                        : 1;  /**< Submission queue doorbell. Asserted when host software writes the
02779                                                          doorbell of a SQ that is disabled. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes
02780                                                          SQ enable conditions.
02781                                                          This error should typically result in software posting an invalid
02782                                                          doorbell register (value 0) error status asynchronous event to the host. */
02783     uint64_t flr                          : 1;  /**< Function-level reset interrupt.  This bit is asserted when a PCIe
02784                                                          function-level reset to the function has been initiated. */
02785     uint64_t ccw                          : 1;  /**< Controller configuration write interrupt.  This bit is asserted anytime
02786                                                          the NQM_VF()_CC register is written via PCIe.  This can be used to
02787                                                          notify OCTEON software that the shutdown notification (SHN) and/or
02788                                                          the enable (EN) fields have changed. */
02789 #else
02790     uint64_t ccw                          : 1;
02791     uint64_t flr                          : 1;
02792     uint64_t sq_db                        : 1;
02793     uint64_t sq_db_val                    : 1;
02794     uint64_t cq_db                        : 1;
02795     uint64_t cq_db_val                    : 1;
02796     uint64_t acq_cfg                      : 1;
02797     uint64_t asq_cfg                      : 1;
02798     uint64_t cq_fe                        : 1;
02799     uint64_t sq_fe                        : 1;
02800     uint64_t sli_err                      : 1;
02801     uint64_t reserved_11_63               : 53;
02802 #endif
02803     } s;
02804     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_int_w1s_s         cn73xx;
02805 };
02806 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_int_w1s cvmx_nqm_vfx_int_w1s_t;
02807

02850 /**

02861     uint64_t en                           : 1;  /**< MSI-X enable. If set, MSI-X is enabled. A RO copy of corresponding PCIEEP_CFG044[MSIXEN]. */

02863                                                          copy of corresponding PCIEEP_CFG044[FUNM]. */

02872 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_config cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_config_t;
02873 
02874 /**
02875  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_msix_pba
02876  *
02877  * NQM_VF(x)_MSIX_PBA contains the PCI-standard MSI-X PBA structure for
02878  * function x.
02879  *
02880  * When migrating a function, the current MSI-X state of the function can
02881  * be captured via the following sequence:
02882  *
02883  * (1) Quiet remote host activity for the function. At this point,
02884  *     all corresponding NQM_VF()_CQ()_HDBL should be stable in
02885  *     the function.
02886  *
02887  * (2) Save a copy and reset all of the NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_CTL's
02888  *     in the function.
02889  *
02890  *     After this step, NQM stops sending MSIs for the function
02891  *     to the remote host because all the
02892  *     NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_CTL[MASK]'s are set.
02893  *
02894  * (3) Save a copy of all the NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_ADDR's and
02895  *     reset them.
02896  *
02897  * (4) Read a copy of all corresponding NQM_VF()_CQ()_TAIL in the
02898  *     function.  Let initTAIL[cq] = the NQM_VF()_CQ(cq)_TAIL[TAIL]
02899  *     value read.
02900  *
02901  * (5) Delay long enough to ensure that any NQM_VF()_CQ()_TAIL changes are
02902  *     reflected in the NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_INT_ST's read in the next step.
02903  *
02904  *     A simple method is to wait for each NQM_VF(0..1027)_CPL(0..16)_IFC[COUNT]
02905  *     in the function to be zero at least once (independently) before continuing.
02906  *
02907  * (6) Read a copy of all corresponding NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_INT_ST.
02908  *     let initINTCNTi be the NQM_VF()_VEC(i)_MSIX_INT_ST[INTCNT] value
02909  *     read.
02910  *
02911  * (7) Read a copy of corresponding NQM_VF()_MSIX_PBA. Let
02912  *     PBA = the NQM_VF()_MSIX_PBA[PEND] value read.
02913  *
02914  * (8) Ensure that all CPL/CQ's in the function are both disabled and idle. See
02915  *     the NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE] description.
02916  *
02917  *     The CQ tails should be stable after this step.
02918  *
02919  *     Corresponding NQM_VF()_MSIX_PBA and all
02920  *     NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_INT_ST[INTCNT] in the function
02921  *     should be zero after this step.
02922  *
02923  * (8) For each MSI-X vector used (i), do this:
02924  *
02925  *      a_cq_tail_changed = 0;
02926  *      for each cq
02927  *        if((cq was enabled before this sequence) and
02928  *           (cq had interrupts enabled before this sequence) and
02929  *           (cq used MSI-X vector i before this sequence) and
02930  *           (initTAIL[cq] does not equal the migrated NQM_VF(0..1027)_CQ(cq)_TAIL[TAIL])) then
02931  *                a_cq_tail_changed = 1
02932  *        endif
02933  *      end for
02934  *      if(a_cq_tail_changed or (initINTCNT[i] is not zero)) then
02935  *            PBA<i> = 1
02936  *      endif
02937  *
02938  * (9) Migrate the resultant PBA value together eith the MSIX_ADDR and
02939  *     MSIX_CTL values captured in (2) and (3) above. PBA
02940  *     will be written to NQM_VF()_MSIX_PBA[PEND] when the function is
02941  *     restored.
02942  *
02943  *     For MSI-X vectors that are used, the corresponding PBA bit
02944  *     will be set at this point unless an MSI had already been sent since
02945  *     the CQ's attached to the interrupt vector became non-empty.
02946  *     When PBA gets written to NQM_VF()_MSIX_PBA[PEND] during the
02947  *     restore, the hardware will not allow a PEND bit
02948  *     to be written to a one unless there is a non-empty CQ
02949  *     attached to the MSI-X vector.
02950  *
02951  * (10) Make a copy and reset corresponding PCIEEP*_CFG044[MSIXEN,FUNM].
02952  *
02953  * When restoring a migrated function, the following sequence can
02954  * restore the MSI-X state:
02955  *
02956  * (1) Restore the saved PCIEEP*_CFG044[MSIXEN,FUNM].
02957  *
02958  * (2) Restore the saved NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_ADDR's.
02959  *
02960  * (3) Restore all other state of the function, enabling all SQ's and
02961  *     CQ's.
02962  *
02963  * (4) Write the saved PBA value to NQM_VF()_MSIX_PBA[PEND].
02964  *
02965  *     See the comment in (9) above.
02966  *
02967  * (5) After either the remote host is ready to receive MSIs from the
02968  *     function, or all saved NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_CTL[MASK]'s are
02969  *     clear, or saved PCIEEP*_CFG044[MSIXEN] is clear, or
02970  *     saved PCIEEP*_CFG044[FUNM] is set:
02971  *
02972  *     Restore all NQM_VF()_VEC()_MSIX_CTL's.
02973  */
02974 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_pba {
02975     uint64_t u64;
02976     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_pba_s {
02977 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
02978     uint64_t reserved_17_63               : 47;
02979     uint64_t pend                         : 17; /**< When [PEND<i>] is set, there is a pending message to be sent for the
02980                                                          MSI-X table entry that is NQM_VF()_VEC(i)_MSIX_ADDR and
02981                                                          NQM_VF()_VEC(i)_MSIX_CTL. NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the MSI-X
02982                                                          table entries and functions that are actually present in the hardware.
02983                                                          There is one [PEND] bit per MSI-X table entry. [PEND] bits whose corresponding
02984                                                          MSI-X table entry don't exist are RAZ. The NQM_VF_INT_VEC_E enumeration
02985                                                          describes the individual table entries and [PEND] bits of each function.
02986                                                          See NQM_VF_INT_VEC_E and NQM_VF_MODE_E.
02987                                                          This field is read-only when accessed from an NQM BAR0 (as per PCI MSI-X
02988                                                          standards), writeable internally. Unless there is one or more enabled and
02989                                                          non-empty CQ that is (1) enabled for interrupts and (2) mapped to the
02990                                                          MSI-X table entry, NQM forces the [PEND] bit to zero, and the [PEND]
02991                                                          bit cannot be written to a one. The NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE] documentation
02992                                                          describes when a CQ is enabled. */
02993 #else
02994     uint64_t pend                         : 17;
02995     uint64_t reserved_17_63               : 47;
02996 #endif
02997     } s;
02998     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_pba_s        cn73xx;
02999 };
03000 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_pba cvmx_nqm_vfx_msix_pba_t;
03001 
03002 /**
03003  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_nssr
03004  *
03005  * NQM_VF(x)_NSSR is the NVMe-standard NVM subsystem reset (NSSR) CSR for
03006  * function x. NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the functions that are actually
03007  * present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03008  */
03009 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_nssr {

03011     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_nssr_s {

03014 #else
03015     uint32_t nssrc                        : 32;
03016 #endif
03017     } s;
03018     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_nssr_s            cn73xx;
03019 };
03020 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_nssr cvmx_nqm_vfx_nssr_t;
03021 
03022 /**
03023  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_sq#_base
03024  *
03025  * NQM_VF(x)_SQ(1..16)_BASE are the IO SQ base addresses for function x.
03026  * NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the queues and functions that are actually
03027  * present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03028  *
03029  * This CSR should only be written and should only be migrated when this
03030  * SQ is idle. The corresponding NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] is an enable
03031  * for this SQ. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes SQ idle conditions.
03032  *
03033  * When configuring a new NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0 (i.e. not physically-contiguous)
03034  * SQ, then software must clear this entire CSR before initially enabling
03035  * the SQ.
03036  *
03037  * When configuring a new NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1 (i.e. physically-contiguous) SQ,
03038  * then software must write this CSR to configure [PBA] prior to
03039  * initially enabling the SQ ([PRIP] and [BV] must be written to
03040  * zero during this write).
03041  */
03042 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_base {
03043     uint64_t u64;
03044     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_base_s {
03045 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
03046     uint64_t pba                          : 52; /**< Page base address.  If NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1 (i.e. physically-contiguous)
03047                                                          then [PBA] is a 64-bit memory page aligned pointer (NQM_VF()_CC[MPS]
03048                                                          selects the page size) to the base of the physically contiguous
03049                                                          queue. Software should derive [PBA] from the PRP entry 1 (PRP1)
03050                                                          field (in CDW6+CDW7) of the create I/O submission queue
03051                                                          command in this case. (If CDW11.PC=0 in the create I/O submission
03052                                                          queue command, but NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1 due to small
03053                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[QSIZE], then software must read the first
03054                                                          PRP Entry in the PRP List from host memory, and write it into [PBA].)
03055                                                          If NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0 (i.e. not physically-contiguous)
03056                                                          then [PBA] is managed by hardware during normal
03057                                                          operation. [PBA] can contain a 64-bit memory page aligned
03058                                                          pointer (NQM_VF()_CC[MPS] selects the page size) to the base
03059                                                          of the current page being accessed in this case. */
03060     uint64_t reserved_2_11                : 10;
03061     uint64_t prip                         : 1;  /**< PRP list read in progress. Must always be written to zero by
03062                                                          software.
03063                                                          Managed by hardware during normal operation when
03064                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0 (i.e. not physically contiguous).
03065                                                          When [PRIP] is set, NQM hardware has an outstanding read to
03066                                                          the PRP list. When a PRP list read returns an error,
03067                                                          NQM clears [PRIP,BV]=0,0, clears corresponding
03068                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE]=0, and sets NQM_VF()_INT[SQ_FE]
03069                                                          for the function.
03070                                                          [PRIP] reads as zero when NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1
03071                                                          (i.e. physically contiguous). */
03072     uint64_t bv                           : 1;  /**< When set, [PBA] is valid.
03073                                                          Managed by hardware during normal operation when NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0
03074                                                          (i.e. not physically contiguous). [BV] is often the inverse
03075                                                          of [PRIP] in this case. But [PRIP,BV] may be 0,0 after initialization
03076                                                          before any completions have been sent and after a read error.
03077                                                          When NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1 (i.e.physically contiguous),
03078                                                          the [BV] read value is the corresponding NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE].
03079                                                          [BV] should be written to one by software only on a migration when
03080                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0 (i.e. not physically contiguous).
03081                                                          [BV] should be written to zero by software in all other circumstances. */
03082 #else
03083     uint64_t bv                           : 1;
03084     uint64_t prip                         : 1;
03085     uint64_t reserved_2_11                : 10;
03086     uint64_t pba                          : 52;
03087 #endif
03088     } s;
03089     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_base_s        cn73xx;
03090 };
03091 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_base cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_base_t;
03092 
03093 /**
03094  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_sq#_cc
03095  *
03096  * NQM_VF(x)_SQ(1..16)_CC are the IO submission queue control registers
03097  * for function x. NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the queues and functions
03098  * that are actually present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03099  *
03100  * This CSR should only be written and only be migrated when the SQ is idle.
03101  * The corresponding NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] is an enable for the SQ.
03102  * NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes SQ idle conditions.
03103  */
03104 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_cc {
03105     uint64_t u64;
03106     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_cc_s {
03107 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
03108     uint64_t reserved_28_63               : 36;
03109     uint64_t qsize                        : 12; /**< Queue size. This value plus one defines the size of the submission
03110                                                          queue in entries. The minimum legal size of 2 entries is configured
03111                                                          when QSIZE is set to 1.  The maximum size of 4096 entries is
03112                                                          configured when QSIZE is set to 0xFFF.
03113                                                          Software should derive [QSIZE] from the queue size field
03114                                                          (CDW10.QSIZE) of the create I/O submission queue command. */
03115     uint64_t reserved_1_15                : 15;
03116     uint64_t pc                           : 1;  /**< Physically contiguous. When set, indicates that the queue is
03117                                                          located in physically contiguous host memory pages. When clear,
03118                                                          indicates that the queue locations are identified by a PRP list.
03119                                                          [PC] must be set for an enabled queue when all queue entries
03120                                                          fit within a single page (NQM_VF()_CC[MPS] selects the page size).
03121                                                          Software should derive [PC] from the physically contiguous field
03122                                                          (CDW11.PC) and the queue size field (CDW10.QSIZE) of the create
03123                                                          I/O submission queue command. [PC] should be set when CDW11.PC
03124                                                          is set. [PC] should also be set when CDW11.PC is clear, selecting
03125                                                          a non-contiguous queue, but [QSIZE] is small enough that all
03126                                                          entries fit within a single page. */
03127 #else
03128     uint64_t pc                           : 1;
03129     uint64_t reserved_1_15                : 15;
03130     uint64_t qsize                        : 12;
03131     uint64_t reserved_28_63               : 36;
03132 #endif
03133     } s;
03134     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_cc_s          cn73xx;
03135 };
03136 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_cc cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_cc_t;
03137 
03138 /**
03139  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_sq#_credit
03140  *
03141  * NQM_VF(x)_SQ(0..16)_CREDIT are the submission queue credits for function x.
03142  * Includes both admin and IO queues. NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the queues
03143  * and functions that are actually present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03144  *
03145  * This CSR should only be written and only be migrated when both the corresponding
03146  * CPL/CQ and the SQ are idle. There should only be one corresponding CPL/CQ -
03147  * selected by the Completion Queue Identifier (CQID) specified in the create I/O
03148  * submission queue command for an I/O SQ, or CPL/CQ zero for an admin SQ.
03149  * The corresponding NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE] is an enable for the CPL/CQ.
03150  * NQM_VF()_CQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes CPL/CQ idle conditions. The corresponding
03151  * NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] is an enable for the the SQ. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE]
03152  * describes SQ idle conditions.
03153  */
03154 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_credit {
03155     uint64_t u64;
03156     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_credit_s {
03157 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
03158     uint64_t reserved_12_63               : 52;
03159     uint64_t cred                         : 12; /**< WQE credit. Flow control credit counter that limits the number
03160                                                          of commands and completion in-flight to the NVMe controller
03161                                                          software executing on the CNXXXX CPUs. [CRED] programming
03162                                                          limits NQM_WQE_S and NQM_CPL_ENTRY_S storage requirements
03163                                                          on the OCTEON.
03164                                                          Prior to enabling a new SQ, software should set [CRED] less
03165                                                          than or equal to the maximum number of inflight NQM_WQE_S's
03166                                                          allowed from this SQ, and less than or equal to the maximum
03167                                                          number of NQM_CPL_ENTRY_S's from this SQ that can reside in the
03168                                                          corresponding CPL queue.
03169                                                          NQM hardware decrements [CRED] when it creates a WQE from a command
03170                                                          in the SQ.
03171                                                          NQM hardware increments [CRED] when it moves a CPL completion
03172                                                          queue entry to its CQ and NQM_CPL_ENTRY_S[SQID] selects this
03173                                                          SQ.
03174                                                          NQM will not move a new command from the SQ into a WQE when [CRED]
03175                                                          is zero.
03176                                                          Note that with an admin SQ/CPL/CQ, asynchronous event requests
03177                                                          will normally remain outstanding for long time periods and
03178                                                          will consume [CRED]'s while they do. The initially-configured
03179                                                          admin SQ [CRED] must exceed the asynchronous event request limit
03180                                                          (AERL) specified in the identify controller data structure provided
03181                                                          in response to the identify admin command. */
03182 #else
03183     uint64_t cred                         : 12;
03184     uint64_t reserved_12_63               : 52;
03185 #endif
03186     } s;
03187     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_credit_s      cn73xx;
03188 };
03189 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_credit cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_credit_t;
03190 
03191 /**
03192  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_sq#_ena
03193  *
03194  * NQM_VF(x)_SQ(0..16)_ENA are the submission queue enable CSRs for function x.
03195  * Includes both admin and IO queues. NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the queues
03196  * and functions that are actually present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03197  */
03198 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_ena {
03199     uint64_t u64;
03200     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_ena_s {
03201 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
03202     uint64_t reserved_1_63                : 63;
03203     uint64_t enable                       : 1;  /**< Enables entry movement from the remote host NVMe-standard SQ to
03204                                                          an OCTEON SSO WQE.
03205                                                          This SQ is enabled when all of [ENABLE], corresponding NQM_VF()_CC[EN],
03206                                                          and corresponding NQM_VF()_CSTS[RDY] are set.
03207                                                          The following CSR arrays are related to the submission queues:
03208                                                          <pre>
03209                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_TDBL
03210                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_CREDIT
03211                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_HEAD
03212                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_IFC
03213                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC
03214                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_PRP
03215                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_BASE
03216                                                           NQM_VF()_SQ()_SSO_SETUP
03217                                                           NQM_VF()_ASQ
03218                                                           NQM_VF()_AQA[ASQS]
03219                                                          </pre>
03220                                                          When this SQ is enabled, NQM can move available submission queue
03221                                                          entries from the NVMe-defined admin or IO SQ on the remote host
03222                                                          to an OCTEON-internal SSO entry. When this SQ is not enabled
03223                                                          or no credits are available, NQM will not initiate new movements
03224                                                          on this SQ. (The corresponding NQM_VF()_SQ()_CREDIT[CRED] is the
03225                                                          credit.)
03226                                                          When the effective SQ enable transitions 1->0, NQM is still moving
03227                                                          submission queue entries as long as corresponding
03228                                                          NQM_VF()_SQ()_IFC[COUNT]!=0. Once NQM_VF()_SQ()_IFC[COUNT] is clear
03229                                                          and NQM_VF()_SQ()_BASE[PRIP] is also clear after the effective
03230                                                          enable transitions 1->0, the SQ is idle. SSO will stop receiving
03231                                                          WQE adds from this SQ soon after the SQ becomes idle.
03232                                                          NQM hardware clears [ENABLE] when an SQ entry or PRP list
03233                                                          entry read returns an error. This would happen when the remote
03234                                                          host doesn't allow the function to read the entry, for
03235                                                          example. */
03236 #else
03237     uint64_t enable                       : 1;
03238     uint64_t reserved_1_63                : 63;
03239 #endif
03240     } s;
03241     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_ena_s         cn73xx;
03242 };
03243 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_ena cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_ena_t;
03244 
03245 /**
03246  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_sq#_head
03247  *
03248  * NQM_VF(x)_SQ(0..16)_HEAD are the submission queue head pointers (and associated
03249  * wrap counters) for function x. Includes both admin and IO queues.
03250  * NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the queues and functions that are actually
03251  * present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03252  *
03253  * This CSR should only be written and only be migrated when the SQ is idle.
03254  * The corresponding NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] is an enable for the SQ.
03255  * NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes SQ idle conditions.
03256  */
03257 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_head {
03258     uint64_t u64;
03259     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_head_s {
03260 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
03261     uint64_t reserved_13_63               : 51;
03262     uint64_t head                         : 13; /**< This field contains a combination of a the SQ head pointer and a
03263                                                          wrap count. Managed by NQM hardware during normal operation. The
03264                                                          head pointer identifies the next entry to be read out of the SQ
03265                                                          in host memory.  Whenever the head pointer is used, it
03266                                                          is either incremented by 1 or wrapped back to zero when it is equal to
03267                                                          the size of the SQ.  The wrap count increments each time time the SQ
03268                                                          head pointer wrap and it can be used to disambiguate head pointers
03269                                                          when the SQ is small in order to simplify fused command processing.
03270                                                          The wrap counter = HEAD<11:n> while the SQ head pointer = HEAD<n-1:0>
03271                                                          where n is the number of bits required to specify the SQ size
03272                                                          n = ROUND_UP( LOG_BASE_2( SQ_SIZE ) ).
03273                                                          When configuring a new SQ, then software should clear [HEAD]
03274                                                          before initially enabling the SQ. */
03275 #else
03276     uint64_t head                         : 13;
03277     uint64_t reserved_13_63               : 51;
03278 #endif
03279     } s;
03280     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_head_s        cn73xx;
03281 };
03282 typedef union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_head cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_head_t;

03308 /**
03309  * cvmx_nqm_vf#_sq#_prp
03310  *
03311  * NQM_VF(x)_SQ(1..16)_PRP are the IO SQ PRP list addresses for function x.
03312  * NQM_VF_MODE[VF_MODE] selects the queues and functions that are actually
03313  * present in the hardware. See NQM_VF_MODE_E.
03314  *
03315  * This CSR should only be written and should only be migrated when this
03316  * SQ is idle. The corresponding NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] is an enable
03317  * for this SQ. NQM_VF()_SQ()_ENA[ENABLE] describes SQ idle conditions.
03318  *
03319  * When configuring a new NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0 (i.e. not physically-contiguous)
03320  * SQ, software should write this CSR to configure [PRP] prior to
03321  * initially enabling the SQ.
03322  *
03323  * When configuring a new NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1 (i.e. physically-contiguous) SQ,
03324  * then software need not write this CSR.
03325  */
03326 union cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_prp {
03327     uint64_t u64;
03328     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_prp_s {
03329 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
03330     uint64_t prp                          : 52; /**< PRP list address.  If NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=0 (i.e. not physically-contiguous)
03331                                                          then [PRP] is a 64-bit memory page aligned pointer (NQM_VF()_CC[MPS]
03332                                                          selects the page size) to the base of the (physically contiguous)
03333                                                          PRP list that constitutes the non-physically-contiguous queue.
03334                                                          Software should derive [PRP] from the PRP entry 1 (PRP1)
03335                                                          field (in CDW6+CDW7 of the create I/O submission queue
03336                                                          command) in this case.
03337                                                          If NQM_VF()_SQ()_CC[PC]=1 (i.e. physically-contiguous)
03338                                                          then [PRP] is not used by hardware. */
03339     uint64_t reserved_0_11                : 12;
03340 #else
03341     uint64_t reserved_0_11                : 12;
03342     uint64_t prp                          : 52;
03343 #endif
03344     } s;
03345     struct cvmx_nqm_vfx_sqx_prp_s         cn73xx;

03564                                                          (i.e. NQM is actively coalescing interrupts) for the vector.

03566                                                          for interrupts and (2) mapped to the MSI-X table entry, [INTCNT] is zero.
